anchor.surface_text: In all cases in which a receipt is sought to be taxed as income, the burden lies upon the Department to prove that it is within the taxing, provision. Where however a receipt is of the nature of income, the burden of proving, that it is number taxable because it falls within in exemption provided by the Act lies upon the assessee. The appellant admitted that she had received jewellery and diverse sums of money from Sita Devi and she claimed that these were gifts made out of love and affection. The case of the appellant was that the receipts did number fall within the taxing provision it was number her case that being income the receipts were exempt from taxation because of a statutory provision. It was, therefore, for the Department to establish that these receipts were chargeable to tax.

concepts.interpretation: Burden on Department to prove receipt falls within taxing provision if assessee claims it is not income; burden shifts to assessee only if prima facie income and exemption claimed. Court applies this to hold Department failed to discharge burden.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner submitted that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the nature of the receipt, it is open to the Income-tax Officer to infer that the receipt is taxable, and relied upon the observations made in A. Govindarajulu Mudaliar v. Commissioner of Hyderabad  2  by Venkatarama Aiyar, J., who speaking for the Court observed There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during, the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature.

concepts.interpretation: Applicable where source/nature not disclosed or unsatisfactory (e.g., cash credits); not where source disclosed (gifts from known person) even if nature disputed. Court distinguishes and holds inapplicable here.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider whether the Income-tax Officer was competent to issue a notice under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act for the years 1947-48 and 1950-51, for in our view the property received by the appellant was not remuneration given to her by Sita Devi for services rendered or to be rendered by her.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to companysider whether the Income-tax Officer was companypetent to issue a numberice under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act for the years 1947-48 and 1950-51, for in our view the property received by the appellant was number remuneration given to her by Sita Devi

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide s.34 issue as receipts held not to be income on merits; Department failed to prove remuneration.

holdings.text: By ss. 3 & 4 the Act imposes a general liability to tax upon all income. But the Act does not provide that whatever is received by a person must be regarded as income liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: By ss. 3 4 the Act imposes a general ability to tax upon all income. But the Act does number provide that whatever is received by a person must be regarded as income liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charging sections tax income, not every receipt; applied to hold gifts not automatically income.

holdings.text: In all cases in which a receipt is sought to be taxed as income, the burden lies upon the Department to prove that it is within the taxing provision. Where however a receipt is of the nature of income, the burden of proving that it is not taxable because it falls within an exemption provided by the Act lies upon the assessee. The case of the appellant was that the receipts did not fall within the taxing provision... It was, therefore, for the Department to establish that these receipts were chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: In all cases in which a receipt is sought to be taxed as income, the burden lies upon the Department to prove that it is within the taxing, provision. Where however a receipt is of the nature of income, the burden of proving, that it is number taxable because it falls within in exemption provided by the Act lies upon the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee claimed gifts not income at all, not exemption from income; burden on Department, which failed.

holdings.text: The decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Calcutta Agency Ltd. lends no support to the proposition... That was a case in which the taxpayer was claiming under s. 10(2)(xv) allowance for an expenditure... the burden of proving the necessary facts in that connection was on the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in the Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Calcutta Agency Ltd.  1  lends numbersupport to the proposition which the High Court has enunciated. That was a case in which the taxpayer was claiming under s. 10 2  xv  allowance for an expenditure out of the income of the business

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished as claim for allowance/exemption from business income, not whether receipt is income.

holdings.text: The observation relied upon [in Govindarajulu Mudaliar] does not lay down a proposition that it may be inferred that a receipt is taxable as income because the assessee fails to lead all evidence in support of the case pleaded by him that the receipt is not within the taxing provision... it is open to the Income-tax authorities to raise an inference that a receipt by an assessee is assessable income where he fails to disclose satisfactorily the source and the nature of the receipt. But in this case the source of the income was disclosed by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner submitted that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the nature of the receipt, it is open to the Income-tax Officer to infer that the receipt is taxable, and relied upon the observations made in A. Govindarajulu Mudaliar v. Commissioner of Hyderabad  2  by Venkatarama Aiyar, J.,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent applies only where source/nature undisclosed (cash credits); here source (Sita Devi) disclosed, nature disputed as gift vs remuneration.

holdings.text: It does not appear that any serious attempt was made by the appellant to prove that the receipts under discussion were exempt from tax, because they were casual and non-recurring nature. The appellant's case primarily was that the receipts were not taxable because they were not income chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: when ample opportunity was given to the assessee to explain the nature of the receipts and since the appellant had number chosen to do so, she was number entitled to the exemption under s. 4 3 vii .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal erred in applying s.4(3)(vii) exemption; assessee's case was receipts not income, not casual receipts exemption.

holdings.text: On the first part of the two questions it must be recorded that what the assessee received in the relevant years of account was not assessable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: On the first part of the two questions it must be recorded that what the assessee received in the relevant years of account was number assessable to tax. it is unnecessary to record, as already observed, a finding on the second branch of the question,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof of remuneration despite opportunities; evidence at best suspicion; Department failed burden; source disclosed as gifts.
